chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should set and finance a universal minimum guarantee: access to essential primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency/catastrophic care without medical bankruptcy, while letting people choose among competing public or regulated private plans for anything beyond that floor. Its core jobs are to define evidence-based benefits, use purchasing power to negotiate fair prices, enforce transparency and interoperability, and reward value and outcomes over volume. Private providers, employers, and community organizations should remain central delivery partners, with targeted support to strengthen rural access and reduce administrative waste.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universally available baseline of affordable, high-quality care—especially primary, preventive, mental-health, emergency, and catastrophic coverage—so no one faces medical bankruptcy. It should set clear quality and evidence-based standards, require price transparency, and streamline administration to reduce waste while using targeted subsidies and strong oversight to keep costs sustainable. Within that public floor, policy should preserve individual choice by partnering with local, community, employer, and regulated private options for supplemental coverage and innovation, with measurable outcomes and accountability.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should guarantee that every person can get affordable essential care—primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency services—and strong protection from catastrophic bills, with extra support for seniors, rural areas, and other high-need communities. It should set clear quality standards, require transparent pricing, and simplify billing and data-sharing to cut waste, while paying for results through value-based incentives. At the same time, regulated private plans and providers should be able to offer supplemental options and innovate, so people keep choice while the public guarantee remains reliable and fiscally sustainable.
